title: Acute Gout Diagnosis Rule
description: Risk stratifies for gout vs non-gout arthritis and helps determine which patients benefit most from joint aspiration. A diagnostic rule for acute gouty arthritis in primary care without joint fluid analysis.

parameters.name: hypertension_or_cardiovascular
parameters.description: Hypertension or presence of ≥1 cardiovascular disease (angina, MI, CHF, stroke/TIA, PVD)

result.name: acute_gout_score
result.description: Acute Gout Diagnosis Rule score (0-13 points)

ranges.interpretation: Low likelihood of acute gout (2.2% prevalence). Gout is unlikely, consider alternative diagnoses. Joint aspiration is not typically needed.
Intermediate likelihood of acute gout (31.2% prevalence). Diagnosis remains uncertain. Consider joint aspiration for synovial fluid analysis to confirm diagnosis.
High likelihood of acute gout (80.4-82.5% prevalence). Gout is highly likely. Consider empirical treatment while awaiting confirmation if needed.

references: Janssens HJ, Fransen J, van de Lisdonk EH, van Riel PL, van Weel C, Janssen M. A diagnostic rule for acute gouty arthritis in primary care without joint fluid analysis. Arch Intern Med. 2010 Jul 12;170(13):1120-6. doi: 10.1001/archinternmed.2010.196.

Kienhorst LB, Janssens HJ, Fransen J, Janssen M. The validation of a diagnostic rule for gout without joint fluid analysis: a prospective study. Rheumatology (Oxford). 2015 Apr;54(4):609-14. doi: 10.1093/rheumatology/keu378.
formula: Score = (Male sex × 2) + (Previous arthritis attack × 2) + (Onset within 1 day × 0.5) + (Joint redness × 1) + (1st MTP involvement × 2.5) + (Hypertension/CVD × 1.5) + (Elevated uric acid × 3.5)
notes: Designed for use in primary care settings when joint fluid analysis is not readily available
Applies to adult patients presenting with monoarthritis (single joint involvement)
Should not be used in polyarticular disease, septic arthritis, or recent joint trauma
Joint aspiration remains the gold standard for definitive gout diagnosis
NPV of 95% for scores <4 and PPV of 87% for scores ≥8 in validation study
Cardiovascular diseases include: angina, MI, CHF, stroke/TIA, and peripheral vascular disease
Serum uric acid should ideally be measured when patient is not on urate-lowering therapy
